Building Partnerships to Assist Developing Countries to Reduce the Transfer of Harmful Aquatic Organisms in Ship's Ballast Water (GloBallast Partnerships)
Building Partnerships to Assist Developing Countries to Reduce the Transfer of Harmful Aquatic Organisms in Ships’ Ballast Water (GloBallast Partnerships)
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To assist vulnerable developing countries to implement sustainable, risk-based mechanisms for the management and control of shipsâ€™ ballast water and sediments in order to minimize the adverse impacts of aquatic invasive species transferred by ships.

By the end of the project, all partnering countries can demonstrate significant improvement in legal, policy and institutional structures, with corresponding reduced risk of ballast water borne marine bioinvasions

comment.narrative:
Although the International Convention on Ballast Water Management was adopted in 2004, minimal ratification by developing countries and no legal, policy and institutional framework in place in most of the developing countries.
No regional approaches and strategies developed to address ballast water issues at regional level and very little regional cooperation on this transboundary issue.
No tools and guidelines to support legal, policy and institutional reform process to address ballast water issues and limited or no technical and institutional capacity to address the issue in most of the developing countries

Lead Agency (LA), National Task Force (NTF) and National Ballast Water Management Strategy (NBWMS) in place in 13 Lead Partner Countries (LPC).
3 Partnering Countries (PC) developed draft NBWMS.
All LPCs drafted National Legislation to support compliance monitoring and enforcement and identified a financing strategy to support the national ballast water management program.
All LPCs are proceeding towards ratification of the IMO BWM Convention.
The regional environmental conventions in GloBallast Partnerships (GBP) regions include provisions supporting BWM convention and regional strategies.

All 15 LPCs have fully functional NTF and identified LAs. 15 LPCs have drafted NBWMS and 11 have officially adopted it. The remaining 4 are on track to adopt it. National interventions to initiate national strategy development in 50 non-LPCs either through GloBallast PCU/RCOs missions to the countries or via twinning between a LPC and a neighbouring PC.
National legislation passed by 3 LPCs (Croatia, Colombia and Nigeria). Draft National Legislation developed by 12 LPCs (Argentina, Chile, Egypt, Nigeria, Ghana, Jordan, Turkey, Jamaica, Panama, Trinidad & Tobago, Venezuela and Yemen). Bahamas have started studying possible revision of existing legislation on marine pollution to include BWM or drafting of new legislation. 14 LPCs have completed national ballast water status assessment. 11 LPCs have drafted national economic assessment and 4 LPCs have progressed well in this activity. 6 LPCs (Croatia, Egypt, Jordan, Nigeria, Trinidad and Tobago and Turkey) have ratified the BWM Convention. Ratification of the BWM Convention is also well underway in Argentina.
2 LPCs received a hands-on training on sampling and analysis of ballast water with on board training on a ship. These trainings were also replicated at the regional level for 7 LPCs (Croatia, Turkey, Nigeria, Ghana, Egypt, Jordan and Yemen), in Turkey, with also the visit of a marine laboratory.
All LPCs have contributed to the Regional Strategy Development process in their respective regions. In 5 regions, the RTF has finalized the Regional Strategy (CPPS, Caspian, PERSGA, MED and WCAR). In the CPPS and MED, the regional strategies have been adopted by the respective regional environmental conventions. MED has an interim ballast water management regime. WCAR and Caspian Regional BWMS were endorsed by the respective regional Convention meetings. SPREP has a fully approved and operational Regional Strategy on marine invasive species in general. Draft regional strategies have been developed in two other non-GBP regions (East Asia and South Asia).

description.narrative: Learning, evaluation and adaptive management increased

No global, regional or national institutional framework to support the objectives of the Project. However, some capacity exists in GloBallast phase 1 countries that could be utilized. Limited global partnerships to support information exchange and capacity building

comment.narrative: No global, regional or national institutional framework to support the objectives of the Project. However, some capacity exists in GloBallast phase 1 countries that could be utilized. Limited global partnerships to support information exchange and capacity building.

Smoothly functioning Project Coordination mechanism, Programme Coordination Unit and monitoring and reporting system in place
Global, Regional and National level steering committees, GEF-UNDP-IMO Executive Committee and specific Task Forces in place to support and advise on project activities and post-project arrangements. Three GPTF meetings, 15 RTF meetings and 65 NTF meetings held during the course of the Project.
Strategic Partnerships developed with two non-GBP regions and five other global and regional institutions to support outreach activities in line with the overall objective of the project
GloBallast outreach and replication by sharing GloBallast experiences and tools through a minimum of 15 international / regional forums and meetings.

Fully functional three-member Programme Co-ordination Unit at IMO plus one temporary administrative assistant and Project Implementation Plan (PIP) and coordination structure in place.
Regional Coordination Organizations (RCO) in place, agreements extended (CPPS, PERSGA) and functional in all GBP Regions apart from WACAF where the GCLME/IGCC ceased to exist. Here, the GloBallast works with IMO’s Regional Coordinator in Ghana. The new MoU between UNEP and Curacao is being discussed as well as the future MoU between IMO and RAC/REMPEITC.
MoAs for financial arrangements in place with all RCOs. Project Task Forces in place at Global (GPTF), Regional (RTF) and National levels (NTF) to support Project implementation. GloBallast Global Legal Task Force (GLTF) established to support project activities.
As of 30 June 2015, 4 GPTF, 6 ExCom meetings, 18 RTF meetings and at least 65 NTF meetings held.
Strategic Partnerships formalized with four International Organizations (IUCN, IOI, WMU and IMAREST) through Letters of Agreements (LOAs). Strategic Partnership established with EBRD through IMO-EBRD Marine Biosafety Initiative (MBI) for EBRD Regions. Strategic Partnership established on training and awareness raising with the ASCLME Project, with particular focus on knowledge transfer between the two GEF-funded projects. Global Industry Alliance Partnership established with four founding industry partners (Vela, BP, DSME and APL) and additional one member (Keppel).
GloBallast Partnerships outreach and awareness raising through at least 64 global and regional forums.

description.narrative: BWM Strategies in place, with legal, policy and institutional reforms developed, implemented and sustained at national level

At project conclusion, each LPC is implementing an effective program of ballast water management in line with the IMO Convention and any Regional Strategies. During the project, each LPC is sharing the lessons learned with other countries in the region

comment.narrative: Very little attention to the BW issue in GBP regions. No regulations, CME systems or institutional arrangements in LPCs to address the BW issue, due to capacity limitations. Maritime administrations are in place in all LPCs. No regional strategies developed in any of the GBP regions.

Technical and institutional capacity enhanced to implement LPI reforms in LPCs and PCs, with the assistance of guidelines and templates developed by the Project.
National Ballast Water Management Strategies and Institutional arrangements to implement the Strategy in all LPCs
Revised legal structures, improved CME systems and a cadre of trained experts in all LPCs
Enhanced Regional cooperation and sharing of experiences through agreeing a Regional Strategic Action Plan in each GBP region

GloBallast Introductory BWM Training Package developed in five languages (Arabic, English, French, Spanish and Russian) to support technical and institutional capacity-building. In addition, 4 specialized training packages developed (Operational aspects, Legal, PBBS and CME). 3 of these advanced training packages have been translated into at least 3 UN languages. The CME training package has been updated to include a new chapter on Sampling based on the new guidance developed at IMO and practical training has been delivered for sampling on board ships and analysis in laboratories.
All 15 LPCs have fully functional NTF and identified LAs. 15 LPCs have drafted NBWMS and 11 have officially adopted it. The remaining 4 are on track to adopt it. National interventions to initiate national strategy development in 50 non-LPCs either through GloBallast PCU/RCOs missions to the countries or via twinning between a LPC and a neighbouring PC.
National legislation passed by 3 LPCs (Croatia, Colombia and Nigeria). Draft National Legislation developed by 12 LPCs (Argentina, Chile, Egypt, Nigeria, Ghana, Jordan, Turkey, Jamaica, Panama, Trinidad & Tobago, Venezuela and Yemen). Bahamas have started studying possible revision of existing legislation on marine pollution to include BWM or drafting of new legislation.
14 LPCs have completed national ballast water status assessment. 11 LPCs have drafted national economic assessment and 4 LPCs have progressed well in this activity. 6 LPCs (Croatia, Egypt, Jordan, Nigeria, Trinidad and Tobago and Turkey) have ratified the BWM Convention. Ratification of the BWM Convention is also well underway in Argentina.
2 LPCs received a hands-on training on sampling and analysis of ballast water with on board training on a ship. These trainings were also replicated at the regional level for 7 LPCs (Croatia, Turkey, Nigeria, Ghana, Egypt, Jordan and Yemen), in Turkey, with also the visit of a marine laboratory.
All LPCs have contributed to the Regional Strategy Development process in their respective regions. In 5 regions, the RTF has finalized the Regional Strategy (CPPS, Caspian, PERSGA, MED and WCAR). In the CPPS and MED, the regional strategies have been adopted by the respective regional environmental conventions. MED has an interim ballast water management regime. WCAR and Caspian Regional BWMS were endorsed by the respective regional Convention meetings. SPREP has a fully approved and operational Regional Strategy on marine invasive species in general. Draft regional strategies have been developed in two other non-GBP regions (East Asia and South Asia).

description.narrative: Knowledge management tools and marine monitoring systems are effectively utilized to expand global public awareness and stakeholder support, improved understanding of ballast water impacts on marine ecology, and enhance maritime sector communications

Sufficient information is available by the end of the project for LPCs to implement risk-based ballast water management systems. All LMEs and Regional Seas programs globally have raised ballast water management as an important coastal zone concern, with their members taking steps to address the issue. Momentum on GBM is sustained in the GB pilot regions.

comment.narrative: Very limited information available to port and coastal states on the risk of ballast water mediated AIS introductions. There is no centralized information sharing mechanism on ballast water management requirements by various States. Patchy information on existing invasive species in port waters. Limited capacity in undertaking any port baseline surveys to assist with ballast water strategy development

Capacity built in undertaking port biological baseline surveys through six regional training courses leading to collection of enhanced information on port biological baseline in all GBP regions
Architecture for a Global Marine Electronic Information System for Biosecurity (GMEISB) and the System components identified.
GloBallast GMEISB Portal functions as a global information clearing house mechanism with built in electronic discussion forum and Country Profile Databases showing ballast water protocols and strategies in different regions and countries, that is updated on a regular basis by participating countries
Capacity built in various LPCS on marine biosecurity knowledge management, supported through national level GMEISB portals
GloBallast Port Environmental Parameters Database (GPED) updated to include at least 400 ports and the same used by several GEF and non-GEF countries to undertake ballast water risk assessments.

Four guidance documents (ballast water status assessment, economic impact assessment, national strategy development and model legislation) were developed and have been disseminated to wider stakeholders through GloBallast website. Most of these tools have been translated into Arabic, French, Spanish and Russian.
Protocols for Port Biological Baseline Survey (PBBS) developed and a related training package developed in cooperation with NIWA New Zealand. The Guidance on Port Biological Baseline Surveys (PBBS, GloBallast Monograph 22) has been developed in partnership with IUCN, IOI-SA and NIO and has been published. Regional level PBBS training completed in all six GBP regions, one LPC (Nigeria) and two non-GBP regions (Black Sea and Caspian Sea). Four LPCs (Croatia, Turkey, Jamaica and Ghana) and one Pilot Country (India) allocated significant national resources to conduct port biological baseline surveys in key ports. All regional strategies include the recommendation to perform PBBS. Following the implementation of BWM measures, PBBS can provide an effective means of evaluating the effectiveness of these measures in preventing new NIS introductions. The conduct of PBBS will also prove useful when port surveys have to be carried out for granting exemptions under the BWM Convention.
Translation of the Monograph 21 on Identifying and managing risks from organisms carried in ships’ ballast water, developed in partnership with WMU, in Arabic and Spanish.
Country Profile Database (CPD) developed and pilot tested with two LPCs (Turkey and Croatia). CPD Training provided in one region (MED). CPD populated by four LPCs so far. All countries participating in national or regional seminars or training are now requested to fill in a country profile form and the information provided will help populate the CPD. This information will also avoid discrepancies with the information provided by member States to IMO through GISIS.
Three LPCs (Croatia, Turkey and Venezuela) developed web-portal on ballast water management and five others have country-specific webpages/awareness materials on ballast water issues (Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, Colombia and Panama).
GloBallast Port Environmental Parameters Database (GPED) updated to include at least 400 ports and the same used by several GEF and non-GEF countries to undertake ballast water risk assessments. Developed draft guidelines for risk assessment in partnership with WMU.
Development of a new website and also a new learning portal that includes a free online e-learning course on the operational aspects of BWM.

description.narrative: Public-private partnerships developed to spur the development of cost-effective ballast water technology solutions
Cost effective technology solutions and testing standards are developed, tested and promoted through a successful partnership with industry

comment.narrative: Private sector involvement is mainly limited to ballast water treatment technology developments and very limited efforts to enabling activities for market transformation and acceptance, and diffusion of technologies within the shipping industry. Very limited communication between private sector and policy makers at local level. Lack of QA/QC standards for facilities that test treatment technologies resulting in resistance from industry to accept technologies. Fragmented R&D efforts and lack of scientific forums to share R&D information.

Global Industry Alliance for Marine Biosecurity (GIA) is launched, a GIA Fund Established (formerly referred to as BWM Innovation Fund in the UNDP ProDoc), test facility standards developed, sediment facility options identified and at least 2 global ballast water R&D symposiums/forums held.

Global Industry Alliance for Marine Biosecurity (GIA) is launched, a GIA Fund Established (formerly referred to as BWM Innovation Fund in the UNDP ProDoc), test facility standards developed, sediment facility options identified and 5 global ballast water R&D symposiums/forums held.
In March 2009, GloBallast formally launched the GIA with financial participation from four major shipping industry leaders (BP Shipping, DSME, APL and Vela Marine International (subsidiary of Saudi Aramco). A GIA Fund (formerly referred to as BWM Innovation Fund) was established with IMO being the fiduciary of the Fund. The starting capital of the Fund was US$200,000, (contributed by the GIA founding partners), currently reaching US$ 350,000. A GIA Industry Task Force (ITF) established and is chaired by GIA member. 8 TF Meetings held to select the projects to be supported by GIA Fund.
GIA initiated the Global Expert Workshop on Port-based Contingency Plan for BWM. The second workshop gathered 23 participants representing expertise from the Shipping Industry, test facilities, Port Operators and Administrators, BWT Research (Academia and NGOs), Technology Developers, and IMO. Thinking that there are alternative means of compliance is a trend that will increase and further to the workshops, papers supporting this idea have been submitted to the IMO.
7 ICBWM (International Conference and Exhibition on BWM, with Singapore). Completed a scientific study on ballast water treatment technology equivalency standards to support alternative ballast water management approaches. Jointly published by GloBallast and GESAMP. Developed an Advanced Training Package on the Operational Aspects of BWM, with significant co-financing from IMO ITCP.
Organized 6 GloBallast test facility standard harmonization workshops and significant progress achieved in development of test facility standards and an MOU between the Test Facilities creating the “GloBal TestNet”. The MoU establishing the GloBal TestNet was signed in October 2013 by representatives of 16 ballast water treatment system testing organizations to facilitate increased standardization and harmonization of test procedures and information exchange. This is considered as a significant milestone which will now accelerate the development of more technical solutions.
Organized a first ever Shipbuilders’ Forum on the BWM Convention (with IMarEST) in Singapore November 2010, a second one in Istanbul, October 2011. The forum was renamed Shipping Industry Forum in Republic of Korea in 2013. GEF intervention through GloBallast played a catalytic role in transforming an entirely new ballast water technology market, now estimated to be worth over US$45 billion in the next 10 to 15 years’ time.
The 3rd GIA Task Force Meeting approved a set of activities planned to be undertaken under the GIA Communication and Awareness Raising for Environmental Sustainability (GIA CARES) programme. As a result and making use of the new developments in information and communication technologies, the GIA has co-financed the conversion of the existing Advanced Training course on BWM and the CME one to an e-learning package, which allows a much wider reach to the shipping industry – and all stakeholders in general. The e-learning package development has been finalized and the brand new GloBallast learning portal was released in April 2015.
A GloBallast-EBRD Marine Biosecurity Initiative (MBI) was launched to assist the private sector in the Bank regions to address ballast water issues and to build capacity among private sector stakeholders. Funding mobilized by EBRD, training managers subcontracted, and two-phase trainings took place in Ukraine, Russian Federation, Turkey and Georgia. EBRD and GloBallast collaborated in the production of a guidance document, poster and presentation to promote the IMO-EBRD Marine Biosafety Initiative amongst other International Financial Institutions.

title.narrative: Assisting LDCs to advance their NAPs

description.narrative: Assisting Least developed Countries (LDCs) with country-driven processes to advance National Adaptation Plans (NAPS)

title.narrative: PIMS 5246 NAPGSP LDCFI UNDPUNITAR agreement signed Jan 2014

description.narrative: Assisting LDCs to advance their NAPs
PIMS 5246 -Global LDC-NAPs_GIZ
To strengthen institutional and technical capacities for iterative development of comprehensive NAPs in LDCs

Number of countries sensitised on functional and operational individual, institutional and systemic capacities required to develop and advance medium- to long-term National and sub-national Adaptation Plans and budgets including use of national systems through Ministries of Finance and local government to channel climate adaptation finance

comment.narrative:
Almost all LDCs have finalised and are at various stages of implementation of their urgent and immediate adaptation plans (NAPAs) with each having different levels of capacity to do so and unclear or overlapping mandates of institutions.
Some LDCs have reported on long-term climate scenarios and their impacts under their National Communications with some having also reported on adaptation options and/or technologies as well as plans to integrate climate change adaptation into long-term planning processes.
Some LDCs are advancing sector specific and cross-sectoral adaptation and development processes through low emission-climate resilient development, green economy, environment-poverty mainstreaming and others with limited coordination between these initiatives
Weak institutional planning processes and mechanisms to pull together and build on from achievements realised through the NAPA formulation and implementation process
All LDCs have been sensitised on functional and operational individual, institutional and systemic capacities required to develop and advance medium- to long-term National Adaptation Plans

Except for Haiti and Myanmar, all LDCs have been sensitized on functional and operational individual, institutional, and systemic capacities required to develop and advance medium – to long-term NAPs, thanks to the project (regional sensitization workshops delivered by UNEP covered all LDCs; however Haiti and Myanmar representatives were unable to attend).

description.narrative: Least Developed Countries are capacitated to advance medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes in the context of their national development strategies and budgets

Number of country-specific national and subnational finance strategies building on national systems developed to enable countries with processes to move forward with medium- to long-term climate resilient planning and budgeting process including the use of budget markers to track climate adaptation expenditure
Number of countries with institutional arrangements and trained capacities in place to advance towards medium- to long-term climate resilient planning and budgeting at national and subnational levels

comment.narrative:
Almost all LDCs have developed urgent and immediate plans for adaptation and other related climate change strategies and started their implementation with some having coordination mechanisms in place to integrate them into the development process as well as other elements which could be used for medium- to long-term planning
Almost all LDCs report on lack of capacity, data, expertise, institutions and financial resources to undertake medium- to long -term orientated impact assessment and adaptation planning;

By the end of the project at least 12 LDCs requesting support from this initiative have conducted needs assessments, identified inputs required and finalised NAP papers to advance to medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes
By the end of the project at least 12 LDCs requesting support from this initiative have trained capacities and clear institutional mandates in place to move towards adaptation planning processes in the context of their development strategies

15 requesting countries have received support in the form or NAP training and or stock-taking exercises (including needs assessments) to advance their NAP process: Bangladesh, Benin, Burkina Faso, Cambodia, Comoros, DRC, Djibouti, Gambia, Liberia, Madagascar, Malawi, Mauritania, Niger, Tanzania, Senegal.
15 LDCs technically supported by the NAP GSP have designated institutional focal points to advance the NAP process. This is the first step of gaining an institutional mandate which is a more complex process requiring endorsement by political actors at the Minister, Prime Minister or National Climate Change Policy making bodies.

description.narrative: Tools and approaches to support key steps of the National Adaptation Plan process are developed and accessible to all LDCs

Number of technical tools, detailed methodologies (by sector) available to support medium- to long-term adaptation planning and planning in all key sectors and at national and sectoral levels drawing on skills of both climate experts and public financial management experts
Number of case studies for medium- to long-term adaptation planning and budgeting developed drawing on both climate experts and public financial management experts

comment.narrative:
There exists limited knowledge on VIA among LDCs, it is not organised, well communicated and remains scarcely understood except in academic settings.
Some guides for assessing and designing adaptation exist, but are weak in methods to cost, prioritise and design national programmes covering all key sectors and targets.
Policy guidance for integrating climate change adaptation into national development planning is weak.

By the end of the project, appropriate guides and related resource materials developed and dispersed through workshops and existing knowledge dissemination websites (APAN, ALM),
At least 5 case studies on the impact of the applications of the guides and other resource materials developed
This Outcome is implemented by UNEP. (N/A)

description.narrative: Exchange of lessons and knowledge through South-South and North-South Cooperation to enhance capacities to formulate and advance the National Adaptation Plan process

Number of region-specific knowledge exchange forums conducted focused on formulating and preparing NAPs (UNEP)
Number of partnerships with global and regional knowledge management institutions established to support countries with NAPs (UNDP)

comment.narrative:
Relevant government entities and other stakeholders in LDCs have limited knowledge of available tools and methods to support their effort in advancing to medium- to long-term adaptation planning processes in the context of their development strategies
LDC government entities have limited partnerships with global and regional institutions to implementing urgent and immediate adaptation needs and no partnerships for medium- to long-term adaptation planning.
No communication and outreach strategy for support to medium- to long-term adaptation planning.
No newsletter or other communication tools for support to medium- to long-term adaptation planning in place as yet
At least 5 partnerships with global and regional knowledge management institutions established to support countries with NAPs

This Outcome is jointly implemented by UNEP and UNDP. Under UNDP's target: 6 partnerships have been established for exchange of knowledge through South-South and North-South Cooperation.
Partnership 1: UNDP and UNITAR have teamed up to focus on skills assessment approaches and sharing these with countries. A skills developed approach has been developed and shared with LDCs at the NAP Expo in 2015 in a dedicated session involving Haiti, Madagascar, Djibouti and Timor-Leste. Non-LDCs also participated in this session.
Partnership 2: UNDP and the Global Water Partnership have established a partnership to collaborate to support LDCs and non-LDCs on the NAPS process and the Economics of Adaptation Capacity Building Programme. This partnership has enabled Africa and Asia and North-South exchange at the NAP GSP regional work-shops in Asia, and Anglophone and Francophone Africa.
Partner 3: UNDP, UNITAR and GIZ have established a partnership for rolling out a jointly developed country level NAP training programme which has been jointly developed, and has been consulted with the UNFCCC and the LDC Expert Group. This has been rolled out in several countries as part of the NAP-GSP support and exchange between LDCs on some of the modules has taken place in the LDC Expert Group regional training work-shops.
Partnership 4: UNDP and UNISDR are in a collaborative partnership to integrate Disaster Risk Reduction into Adaptation Planning. The guidelines is being developed through south-south exchange meetings such as a side event at SBI in June 2015 with over 80 participants with over 10 LDCs.
Partnership 5; FAO and UNDP are jointly partnering on integrating the agricultural sectors into the NAPs process. Based on the NAP-GSP initial collaboration, UNDP and FAO are now supporting 8 countries on NAPs through a BMUB supported initiative.
Partnership 6: The NAP-GSP has linked up with the UNDP Adaptation Learning Mechanism to serve as a knowledge management tool featuring support to requesting countries and for the production of a e-newsletter that goes to over 1200 subscribers. The e-newsletter initially issued every month is now issued around key global and regional events related to climate change and is issued 3-4 times in the year.
The NAP-GSP website is operational and an e-intro on NAP support was produced by NAP-GSP and UNITAR. Existing web-based training materials from other partners were explored (for example, webinars on climate smart agriculture from FAO and GIZ’s webinars on insights into National Adaptation Planning, APAN’s knowledge sharing series on NAPs, etc.) and made available as part of the NAP-GSP website and/or disseminated through quarterly newsletters. Full national training material packages for the Regional and National NAP Training Workshops are also available as key knowledge products on the NAP-GSP website.
Newsletters are issued around key global events, and an online database of subscribers now numbers over 2,200. All existing materials in the NAP website have been integrated into NAP Central.
Existing networks and initiatives are widely used as platforms to promote thematic discussions on NAPs: APAN, AAKNET, and UNDP ALM, UNDP ECCA, and SEAN CC. In addition to the above, the NAP-GSP monthly e-newsletters and the NAP-GSP portal regularly feature outcomes and lessons from country missions, promoting South-South knowledge transfer.
Further, the NAP GSP teamed up with the LDC Expert Group in their side events at CoP and held numerous side events at SBI and COP, where NAP GSP showcased best practices and results.

title.narrative: PIMS 3527-Capacity Building for PCB Elimination in Ghana

description.narrative: PIMS 3527-Capacity Building for PCB Elimination in Ghana
Capacity Building for PCB Elimination in Ghana
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Objective: to enhance the capacity for the safe management of PCB oil and PCB-containing equipment at all stages of the PCB management cycle.
1. Institutional and normative frameworks strengthened for the management of PCB throughout their life-cycle.

comment.narrative: No meaningful institutional / normative frameworks in place.
As per indicator

The following technical guidelines have been completed and published during the current reporting period:
1. Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines for PCBs
2. National PCB Management Plan for Ghana, and
3. Community Strategy for POPs management
The Draft Bill, entitled "Hazardous and Electronic Waste Control and Management Bill, 2015", has been finalized.
The Draft Bill has been reviewed by the Ministry of Justice so as to ensure consideration and approval by the Parliament. A specific presentation of the new legislative draft was made to parliamentarians in 2015 to explain and encourage supporters of the legislation when it is presented in the Parliament. December 2015 is a realistic target for parliamentary consideration and approval of the BILL. The Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI) is actively pursuing this matter.

description.narrative: 2. Technical capacities enhanced for the identification and sound management of PCB contaminated equipment.

comment.narrative: Very limited technical capacities existing in country for PCB management practices.
As per indicator

Additional 35 experts were trained during the lessons learnt and training Workshop held in October 2014 by an international expert as well as Veolia, in the following areas:
1. Obsolete Pesticides - Health and Environmental Hazards and exposure management
2. Phase-out of PCB containing equipment (handling and interim storage platforms)
3. Measuring toxicity and finding out about pesticides
4. Disposal Options for POPs - High Temperature Incineration and Off-site decontamination of PCB Equipment
5. Transport of wastes
6. Disposal operations (packaging, transportation, treatment and disposal)
7. Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs)
8. Demonstration on the use of PPEs
9. Emergency planning
10. Safeguarding – Introduction and zoning / Safe working methods
11. Safeguarding – Introduction to task based risk assessment

description.narrative: 3. Replacement and safe disposal of 160 tons of PCB-containing transformers and capacitors.

comment.narrative: Zero tonnes of pure PCB containing equipment replaced/displaced.
As per indicator

159 tons of integrated wastes (60 tons of PCB wastes [Pure PCB concentrated oils - 41 tons , 5 tons PCB contaminated oils - oil from flushing of drained transformers containing PCBs, 9 tons PCB capacitors, 5 tons PCB contaminated equipment and wastes - such as test kits, oil samples, containers including soils], 93 tons, Obsolete POPs Pesticides and 6 tons of ODS materials) disposed of in Poland through high temperature incineration. Obsolete POPs Pesticides as well as PCB disposal was financed under the GEF funded Ghana PCB capacity building project. The disposal for the ODS materials was fully financed under the Montreal Protocol by the Multilateral Fund (Pilot Project on ODS destruction). The certificates of destruction had not been received yet as of 30 June 2015.

description.narrative: 4. Safe disposal of 450 tons of contaminated material including 120 tons of PCB-contaminated oil and associated non-recyclable waste streams.

comment.narrative: Zero tonnes of contaminated PCB containing equipment replaced/displaced.
As per indicator

The procurement of international PCB disposal services were completed, the safe transportation, packaging and export of PCBs, pesticides and ODS waste was completed by June 2015 - making this project one of the few UNDP/GEF projects that have supported the disposal operation of different types of wastes (60 tons PCBs, 93 tons Obsolete POPs pesticides and 6 tons ODS to be destroyed in one single disposal facility in Europe). As per the project document, the main global benefit from the project [was] the safe disposal of an estimated 40 tons of pure PCB oil and 120 tons of PCB-contaminated oil, i.e. in total 160 tonnes of hazardous substances. By achieving 159 tonnes of safe disposal (although of different substances than the ones initially planned, i.e. 96% of POPs and 4% of ODSs), the project achieved 99.4% of the target.

description.narrative: 5. Project methodologies replicated for other relevant chemicals issues.

comment.narrative: No methodologies to replicate.
As per indicator

The following workshop has been used as a platform for sharing Lessons learnt: PCB management Lessons Learnt and Training Workshop, 27 -29 October 2014, Accra, Ghana.
Lessons learned through this project implementation thus continued being shared with neighboring countries faced with similar challenges (in addition to workshops/events in previous reporting periods that also targeted this objective) - for possible replication. The following countries have participated in the workshop mentioned above: Angola, Kenya and Ethiopia.

description.narrative: 6. Financial and substantive project management capacities strengthened and experience replicated to other projects.

comment.narrative: No meaningful capacity exists.
As per indicator

Project management capacity has been built, particularly in the Ghana EPA, which can be used for implementation of other chemicals-related projects.
The importance of the long-term responsibility of the Ghana EPA in making sure the project results are sustained in the future has been underlined in last steering committee meeting.

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Strengthening of the legal framework, administrative and technical preparedness for sound PCB management
1. Review, develop, and adopt legislation and policies

comment.narrative: No legislation and policy on PCB in place
Legislation and policy on PCB covering their lifecycle.

The Environment, Health and Safety guidelines have now been published. The draft legislation has not been adopted yet, but the Ghana EPA continues to provide regular follow-up throughout the review process by the Ministry of Justice to ensure its consideration and approval by Parliament. December 2015 is the target for Parliamentary approval.

description.narrative: 2. Capacity building for sound PCB management in the public sector (authorities)

comment.narrative: Authorities without proper knowledge of PCBs and related exposure risks and without management capacities.
Authorities capable of handling PCBs throughout their lifecycle.

35 additional experts have been trained by an international expert and Veolia (the company in charge of the disposal operation) during the lessons learned and training workshop conducted in October 2014 in Accra, Ghana.
Experts were trained in the following areas:
1. Obsolete Pesticides - Health and Environmental Hazards and exposure management
2. Phase out of PCB containing equipment (handling and interim storage platforms)
3. Measuring toxicity and finding out about pesticides
4. Disposal Options for POPs - High Temperature Incineration and Off-site decontamination of PCB Equipment
5. Transport of wastes
6. Disposal operations (packaging, transportation, treatment and disposal)
7. Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs)
8. Demonstration on the use of PPEs
9. Emergency planning
10. Safeguarding – Introduction and zoning / Safe working methods
11. Safeguarding – Introduction to task based risk assessment

description.narrative: 3. Capacity building for sound PCB management (PCB holders) through a series of topic-specific training workshops

comment.narrative: PCB holders are not aware of the presence of PCB in equipment, related risks and have no capacities to handle contaminated equipment.
PCB holders enabled to develop PCB management, reducing exposure from PCB equipment still in use and develop PCB phase-out plans

As a summary for this line as well as the one above, the total number of trained PUBLIC officers and experts from the PRIVATE sector reached 205. The breakdown is as follows:
1. During the inventory and associated training: 45 people were trained
2. Session during the UNEP-ICCA Project workshop on “Promoting Chemical Safety Management in the African Region” Project launch and training: 50 people were trained
3. Inventory dissemination and training workshop: 30 people were trained
4. Ghana EPA - Utility sector annual training: 45 people have been trained.
5. Lessons learnt and training: 35 people were trained during the training component of the Workshop.

description.narrative: 4. Update and further refine the existing PCB inventory to increase its comprehensiveness

comment.narrative: No inventory and classification of PCB equipment exists
Complete inventory of capacitors and transformers exists and replacement scheme for contaminated equipment is implemented.

Full PCB inventory completed as per previous reporting (60 tons PCB inventoried in total).
Final values are:
Pure PCB concentrated oils - 41 tons (drained PCB oil from transformers)
PCB contaminated oils - 5 tons (oil from flushing of drained transformers containing PCBs)
PCB capacitors - 9 tons
PCB contaminated equipment and wastes - 5 tons (contaminated materials such as test kits, oil samples, containers including soils)
Note: PCB capacitors (number of) - 117 individual pieces.

description.narrative: 5. Develop and implement administrative system for PCB-related enforcement and inspection activities after inventory compilation

comment.narrative: No administrative monitoring of existing equipment.
Authorities empowered to control status of equipment and inspect facilities.

As mentioned above, 35 additional participants have been trained in packaging, handling and trans-boundary movement of hazardous POPs waste during the lessons learned and training workshop conducted in October 2014 in Accra, Ghana.

description.narrative: 6. Institutional and normative frameworks stregthened for the management of PCB throughout their life-cycle.

comment.narrative: Government officials do not have knowledge of PCB problems and lack a legal mandate and institutional framework to address PCBs.
Regulations and instituional mechanisms exist to safely monitor and manage PCBs.

The Draft Bill, entitled "Hazardous and Electronic Waste Control and Management Bill, 2015", has been finalized.
The Draft Bill has been reviewed by the Ministry of Justice so as to ensure consideration and approval by the Parliament. A specific presentation of the new legislative draft was made to parliamentarians in 2015 to explain and encourage supporters of the legislation when it is presented in the Parliament. December 2015 is a realistic target for parliamentary consideration and approval of the BILL. The Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI) is actively pursuing this matter.

description.narrative: Outcome 2: Infrastructure for environmentally sound management of PCBs developed and in place
1. Identify, construct or upgrade of a secure, temporary storage facility(ies)

comment.narrative: No storage facility exists.
Temporary storage in place until full sound disposal of contaminated equipment.

Temporary storage was used until the disposal operations took place.
In February 2015, on the occasion of the re-packaging of the PCB waste on the site by the international supplier of services and its local contractors, the Minister and media were invited to visit the site to witness the operations.
In March 2015, tests were made on site to check whether there was any PCB contamination around the temporary storage.
All tests were negative (below 50 ppm) except one just at 50 ppm and one near this value.
Ghana EPA committed during the final steering committee meeting to follow-up and ensure proper visual identification and warning on that specific site to avoid access to the contaminated spot, and the appropriate remediation of this spot.

description.narrative: 2. Upgrading of transportation safety for PCB-containing equipment and fluids.

comment.narrative: No precautions against PCB exposure exist during transport of decommisioned equipment.
Safe transportation of equipment is possible.

Final transportation took place to collect and consolidate all PCB related waste and equipment in one location before repackaging and export.
Appropriate PPE and precautions were taken during those operations, as per the contract of the international supplier.
The involvement of a local contractor enabled the project to build national capacity in using PPE and best practices in handling PCBs, and hazardous chemicals in general.
An information flyer describing best practices in handling PCB-containing or-contaminated equipment was re-published with improved pictures and text.

description.narrative: 3. Technical capacities enhanced for the identification and sound management of PCB contaminated equipment.

comment.narrative: No capacities for identifying, handling, transporting and storing PCB contaminated equipment.
Technical knowledge for the sound management exists and is shared among professionals.
Activities completed as per the previous reports.

description.narrative: Environmentally sound replacement and disposal of PCB waste and equipment
1. Development of a five year phase-out plan and its implementation for the various waste streams

comment.narrative: No phase-out plan.
Coordinated replacement of contaminated equipment and treatment of waste.
The National PCB Environmental Sound Management Plan has been approved, as per previous planning. Other activities were completed as per previous reports.

description.narrative: 2. Replacement of pure PCB oil containing equipment and associated waste

comment.narrative: PCB contaminated equipment remains in use.
PCB contaminated equipment is phased-out and replaced.
Activities completed as per the previous reports.

description.narrative: 3. Decommissioning, washing, and disposal of phased-out PCB-contaminated mineral oil and equipment in country

comment.narrative: PCB contaminated equipment remains in use.
PCB contaminated equipment is safely handled and decommissioned.
Activities completed as per the previous reports.

description.narrative: 4. Technical capacities enhanced for the identification and sound management of PCB contaminated equipment.

comment.narrative: No capacities for identifying, handling, transporting and storing PCB contaminated equipment.
Technical knowledge for the sound management of PCBs exists and is shared among professionals.

35 people were trained by and international expert and by Veolia the following areas:
1. Obsolete Pesticides - Health and Environmental Hazards and exposure management
2. Phase out of PCB containing equipment (handling and interim storage facilities)
3. Measuring toxicity and finding out about pesticides
4. Disposal Options for POPs - High Temperature Incineration and Off-site decontamination of PCB Equipment
5. Transport of wastes
6. Disposal operations (packaging, transportation, treatment and disposal)
7. Personal Protective Equipment (PPEs)

description.narrative: 5. Project methodologies replicated for other relevant chemicals issues.

comment.narrative: No technical knowledge and methodology for the safe handling of PCB or other POPs contaminated equipment.
Technical knowledge for the sound management of PCBs and other related chemicals (POPs) exists and is shared among professionals.

A Lessons Learnt and Training Workshop whose objective was to share lessons learnt during the course of implementation of the GEF/UNDP/UNITAR/EPA-Ghana Project on Capacity Building for the Elimination of PCBs in Ghana was held in October 2014. The following experiences were shared:
1. Experiences and information on Environmental Sound PCB Management including background knowledge, national oversight structures, inventory, handling, interim storage platforms, trans boundary movement and disposal options shared
2. Information on available international PCB management financing options shared
3. Recommendations on improvements of future PCB management projects were also made.
The training component of the workshop trained on the following: Packaging, handling and trans-boundary movement of hazardous POPs waste
In addition to the local stakeholders, representatives from Angola, Ethiopia, and Kenya also participated in the workshop.

description.narrative: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback, outreach, and evaluation
1. Development and implementation of project monitoring and evaluation tools and systems

comment.narrative: Available monitoring data on PCB collected. Efficient project implementation with resulting local and global environmental benefits.

M&E Committee activities continued during this final reporting period and were regulatory fed into the discussions of the Project Steering Committee (PSC), which gave its feedback and guidance on the overall project activities and programme of work. The PSC met on the following dates: 31 October 2014, 12 February 2015 and 30 June 2015.

description.narrative: 2. Information and outreach

comment.narrative: No information available on PCBs and the project.
Stakeholders and public aware of risks of PCBs and work undertaken to reduce those.

In addition to awareness raising and information dissemination undertaken during previous reporting periods, media coverage was ensured during the re-packaging operations for the PCBs and obsolete POPs (and ODS) pesticides. Link:https://www.modernghana.com/news/598644/1/minister-inspects-toxins-disposal-project.html

description.narrative: 3. External Evaluation

comment.narrative: Monitoring and appraisal of the performance of the project.

The process for the terminal evaluation was launched but not yet completed by the 30 June deadline, due to some administrative delays in processing the contract.
The final report and recommendations will be circulated among the stakeholders interviewed and disseminated as widely as possible, to provide lessons learnt both in Ghana and generally for future similar projects.

description.narrative: 4. Project methodologies replicated for other relevant chemicals issues.

comment.narrative: No technical knowledge and methodology for the safe handling of PCB or other POPs contaminated equipment.
Technical knowledge for the sound management of PCBs and other related chemicals (POPs) exists and is shared among professionals.
Activities completed as per previous reports.

description.narrative: 5. Financial and substantive project management capacities strengthened and experience replicated to other projects.

comment.narrative: No experience in handling a national GEF FSP project.
Knowledge and experienced gained used for and shared with other projects.

On the issue of sustainability after the project, it was indicated during one of the 2015 steering committee meetings that "the project had built-in mechanisms for sustainability after the end of the project and these included the legislation, the PCB management plan and the communication strategy". Additionally, the Ministry of Environment (MESTI) promised to work with the Ghana EPA to make sure the results of this project are built upon and, in particular, that the follow-up on the draft Bill continues up to its approval.

title.narrative: PIMS 5320 MSP UNDP directly implemented Support to 2014

description.narrative: PIMS 5320 MSP UNDP directly implemented Support to 2014 World Park Congress
PIMS 5320 - Parks, People, Planet: Protected areas as solutions to global challenges
To strengthen the capacity for effective management and equitable governance of an ecologically representative global network of protected areas

1. Results from segmented target group surveys completed by individuals who benefitted from project-enabled capacity building activities (main groups are: protected area professionals, planners and policy-makers)

comment.narrative: 1. No surveys have yet been designed or carried out

1. Analytical results from segmented target group surveys clearly document improved knowledge uptake among project beneficiaries for more effective PA governance, planning and management aligned with quality components of Aichi target 11 and emerging priority issues facing PA systems.

Feedback from all Stream Leaders of the 8 core streams and 4 cross-cutting themes of the World Parks Congress facilitated and collated by the project. The results were used to develop a draft, and consult, on the Promise of Sydney (PoS - the outcome documents of the IUCN World Parks Congress). This process was made possible through the project and the PoS was finalized and presented globally. A planned final survey on implementation of the PoS will be carried out in November 2015, one year after the WPC, to provide a more reflective analysis of results by the PA community, and allow for feedback on the direction of post-WPC project products and interventions.

description.narrative: 2. Number and type of good practice guidelines and training modules developed by the end of the project.

comment.narrative: 2. No good practices guidelines or training modules yet developed in the framework of the project.
2. At least 6 good practices and training modules developed and accessed online by a minimum of 500 individuals.

By June 30th 2015 the Panorama solutions portfolio (www.panorama.solutions) lists over 120 documented PA solutions. Over 100 ‘raw’ stories from protected areas were collated during the WPC in November 2014. A curation process assures that documented case studies are credible and relevant to PA practitioners and policy-makers worldwide. A focus on the core elements of success in each case can be isolated, shared, and collated and analysed. Additionally, the UNDP-led NBSAP Forum ‘Best Practices’ sections visited by at least 500 people (www.nbsapforum.net) . This is also promoted strongly by IUCN GPAP and project team. Training materials were developed and promoted with project support in at least 10 events at the World Parks Congress, including advanced materials and method for PA Governance at site and system levels; applying and developing protected area standards; applying marine protected area categories; marine protected area compliance training; participatory approaches to documenting indigenous and traditional ecological knowledge; climate change and protected areas (http://warnercnr.colostate.edu/climate-change-webinar).

description.narrative: 3. Quality of key knowledge products produced by the project, as independently assessed by project evaluator using scoring (criteria and scale t.b.d. in due course, but may e.g. include technical stringency, usefulness, innovativeness and didactical elements).

comment.narrative: 3. No knowledge products yet developed in the framework of the project.
3. Average and combined scoring applied to the quality of key knowledge products produced by the project achieve at least 60%, as per the scale and criteria defined by the independent evaluator.

‘Promise of Sydney’ (PoS) WPC Congress output evaluated by all leads of WPC Streams and Themes, as well as other key contributors. http://worldparkscongress.org/about/promise_of_sydney.html
Feedback form built into the ‘panorama’ beta development website www.panorama.solutions collated from October 2014 to June 2015– feedback also collated during the WPC on specific forms and through pax interviews. Over 80% satisfaction; over 20% of users provided full feedback on content, design, objectives. Further evaluation to be applied in latter stages of project once sufficient use / promotion of materials is achieved.

description.narrative: Knowledge uptake on PAs, facilitated by the ‘strategic platform for development & learning’ provided by the World Parks Congress 2014 and through training delivered through PA learning networks enhances and accelerates the implementation of the CBD’s Programme of Work on Protected Areas (PoWPA) and its Strategic Plan for Biodiversity.
4. Number and type of learning networks identified, engaged, and mobilized to support continued learning on emerging issues highlighted in ongoing training.

comment.narrative: 4. So far, 3 networks have been identified on a preliminary screening (CAFÉ, CFA and REDELAC), but not yet engaged, nor mobilized, to support learning in connection with the project.
4. At least 3 existing or new learning networks are identified, engaged and mobilized to support continued learning on emerging issues.

During the inception meeting, the three pre-identified networks (CFA, CAFÉ and REDLAC) were merged into one umbrella network represented by the Conservation Finance Alliance (CFA). As such, they represent one of six networks for support under the project, not three. This is because the CFA already included engagement and networking of both CAFÉ and REDLAC, and the similar subject matter of each (conservation finance) would narrow the project focus from the full spectrum of protected areas themes.
So far, networks identified / engaged include:
1. CFA – to convene their network members and associated experts and thought-leaders, initially through the World Parks Congress (events across streams, hosted in a CFA-dedicated pavilion). Initial follow-up on strengthening their network institutional robustness, and driving new parameters for the role of impact / responsible investment into protected areas (ongoing).
2. Healthy Parks, Healthy People (HPHP) network. Events at World Parks Congress secured through co-finance and integrated with support for activities across streams and themes. Follow-up engagement through direct project support for translation and development of best practice guidance of issues arising that are directly relevant to GEF-eligible countries, in particular links between urbanisation, health and protected areas.
3. Protected Area Governance Learning network. An emerging network of PA governance practitioners and policy actors identified using the World Parks Congress as the springboard. Specific members supported to attend events, and a dedicated post-WPC networking event sponsored. Follow-on support for activities in specific GEF-eligible geographies supported and ongoing.
4. Inspiring a New Generation (ING) network – a key theme of youth and re-engagement with nature emerged in the pore-Congress planning and from the activities at the event. Support to an umbrella network of ‘ING’ practitioners is ongoing.
5. International Marine Protected Area Managers network. Several connector events were supported at the WPC, including pre-WPC training events on marine and MPA compliance. An emerging theme from the World Parks Congress was the need to network MPA managers in a more inclusive, accessible manner. Initial support to the IMPANA network to deliver capacity through learning materials is being considered.
6. ‘Panorama’ Global Protected Area Solutions and Standards network. The use of PA Solution case studies as part of a network of learning on protected areas is underway, with three principle components; knowledge management; peer-peer connection and sharing of solutions; incentives and commitments from PA managers and practitioners to improve performance through the use of PA standards and associated tools

description.narrative: 5. Analysis of the profiles of target groups.

comment.narrative: 5. Target groups yet to be identified and profiled.

5. Results from profiling applied to project target groups indicate a balanced and effective outreach to protected area professionals, planners and policy-makers enabled by the project, including through the learning networks.

Data for overall attendance at the World Parks Congress indicate a very balanced collection of demographics associated with protected areas, with a majority of protected area professionals. Direct support from the project prioritized ‘those who otherwise would not be able to attend’ – especially women and youth from LDCs and under-represented countries from the GEF-eligible portfolio. Support for such candidates was integrated into the planning of each Stream and cross-cutting theme, to enable a) their own prioritization of resources to similar individuals, and b) to ensure that adequate profiling and participation could be afforded these individuals in the context of event and session planning. Some Streams were more pro-active and able to mobilize resources from other sources, and therefore the allocation of support to participants was based on the applicant, rather than a quota for each thematic area. A total of 109 eligible WPC participants were ide notified and supported to attend, with either full or partial support from the project. Other donors aligned their selection to the project priority selection criteria, including UNESCO and African Development Bank. Of these participants, over 50% were women. Every participant played an active role in at least one WPC event or session, training or network gathering.

description.narrative: 6. Use of metrics in PA assessment and reporting across the GEF portfolio

comment.narrative: [exact baseline t.b.d. upon inception]
6. Improved use of metrics in PA assessment and reporting across the GEF portfolio [target t.b.d. in relation to baseline]

Baseline indicates basic Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) used in GEF portfolio relating to PAs. Data from METT assessments not comprehensively collated across the portfolio. METT relies heavily on project-duration impacts rather than verified reporting on outcomes. Lessons identified are rarely, systematically encapsulated into learning materials. The inception meeting decided that two avenues should be explored; firstly, better capturing of the ‘building blocks’ for successful interventions into protected areas to allow for a critical mass of case studies / knowledge management that can be directly linked to capacity-building and training initiaitves; secondly, a new standard for protected areas that would build outcomes into the current tools and methodologies for management effectiveness, governance and sound planning for conservation of key values.
UNDP mobilization of an adapted template to contribute ‘Best Practices’ into the www.nbsapforum.net provided an initial group of ‘solutions’ to be identified and apply a basic level of reporting on successful interventions.
The project-supported ‘Panorama’ solutions template, and adaptation of UNDP template, allowed cross-referencing of ‘best practices’ into the panorama platform. The Panorama solutions template is evolving through project and partner support, and could now offer a tiered metric for GEF-portfolio projects.
Additionally, IUCN used the project investigations into metrics for protected area outcomes, led by the joint WCPA-SSC Task Force on biodiversity and protected areas, also the focus of several sessions at the World Parks Congress under Stream 1 on Reaching Conservation Goals.
From this work, and the results of the PA Governance events, a new global standard and assurance process has been applied to 14 sites in GEF-eligible countries as part of developing an IUCN global standard for PA performance.
IUCN, as a new GEF implementing agency (since late 2014), will integrate requirements for using the panorama solutions template and the PA Green List Standard as addittional metrics over and above the current METT requirement, for all PA-related projects.

description.narrative: Global learning and technical content development on key protected area issues are enhanced and contribute to practical solutions to current and emerging challenges worldwide.
7. Number of best practice guides, user-friendly online tools and e-modules developed to improve the quality and effectiveness of PA systems.

comment.narrative: 7. No best practices or online tools (incl. e-modules) have yet been developed in the framework of the project.
7. At least 3 best practice guides and 6 on-line tools and e-modules developed for technical support and training to improve the quality and effectiveness of protected area systems.

Best practice guidance contributions supported by the project on several ongoing editions, to be finalized in the latter stages of the project. These include protected area outcomes; protected area governance; healthy parks, healthy people; climate change and protected areas; participatory mapping of indigenous and local ecological knowledge. Online tools include the Panorama platform, youth and young professionals learning network; PAs and climate change platform and webinars. Ongoing engagement with practitioners is needed to identify the best translation of World Parks Congress results into on-line learning tools. Much of this will come from the 6 networks engaged and supported, including the CFA.

description.narrative: 8. Number of learners accessing and availing of best practice guidance and resources, including e-modules; overall satisfaction with materials provided.

comment.narrative: 7. No best practices or online tools (incl. e-modules) have yet been developed in the framework of the project – hence no count metrics for access has been established.

8. Approximately 600 key professionals, who would have been identified, and engaged during the exchange and development of country-case studies and best-practice guidance benefit from knowledge products produced with the project’s assistance.

Over 100 specific participants supported for active participation in World Parks Congress events. Over 150 ‘best practices/ panorama solutions’ identified and attributed to a lead proponent professional. Networking on the development of PA Standards has recorded 202 experts involved in specific evaluation and engagement in applying standards to PAs within GEF-eligible countries. NBSAP forum membership continues to rise, with an increment of 298 since 1st July 2014 to June 30th 2015. Full reporting on numbers engaged will form part of final evaluation, but the project is clearly on track with this metric.

description.narrative: 9. Use of a collaborative framework enables the sharing and promotion of best practices, tools, and guidance.

comment.narrative: 9. No collaborative framework has been established for using and sharing best practices, tools, and guidance.
9. A collaborative framework is identified and used to effectively share and promote best practices, tools and guidance.

The ‘Panorama’ protected area solutions template designed for use by the project and partners to capture the practice and policy case studies and stories, and their component building blocks of success, has been adopted by a number of partners including GIZ, UNEP and GRID-Arendal through the Blue Solutions partnership; by Ecotrust and the Resilience Exchange Network; by Coalition Wild, Blue Ventures, WWF Tiger Programme; The Coral Triangle Initiative; the Micronesia Conservation Trust and Micronesia Challenge Steering Committee; as well as IUCN programmes (marine, forests, SOS and Tiger granting mechanisms). The framework will also be included in IUCN’s portfolio of GEF projects relating to protected areas.
A version of the template is used by UNDP to capture ‘best practices’ on the NBSAP Forum.
Work is ongoing to refine the template, especially to combine ‘harvest’ of data and results for knowledge management with an active networking tool for practitioners to share and reflect on their experience.

description.narrative: 10. User surveys designed to focus on the utility and quality of shared best practices and case studies.

comment.narrative: 10. No user-surveys have yet been designed.
10. Results from user surveys demonstrate the utility and quality of shared best practices and case studies.

User surveys are still under development / yet to be fully analysed as project is still ongoing. However, for the panorama, user surveys have informed product and portal development based on feedback on quality and user access. Specific user feedback form prominent on interim Panorama Solutions portal promoted at the World Parks Congress, with over 50 direct user responses sourced from the site as of 30th June 2015.

description.narrative: Protected areas assume a more prominent role and position within the development policy, economic strategies and human well-being respective agendas
11. Project commitments in at least 5 countries enable integration of PAs into national land-use planning frameworks.

comment.narrative: 11. Countries are preparing for the Parks Congress, but have not yet defined their policy commitments, nor their follow-up actions.
11. Initiatives underway in at least 5 countries to integrate PAs into national/ frameworks and sectoral development plans.

description.narrative: 11a. [as above]

comment.narrative: 11a. [as above]
11a. Recommendations on PA-related policy issues are developed from deliberations at IUCN WPC.

The Promise of Sydney (PoS) document is a complete summary of recommendations related to PA policy and practice emerging from the substance of all streams and cross-cutting themes, and related commitments by all partners, including Governments and international agencies / organisations. The PoS was fully supported by the project.

description.narrative: 11b. [as above]

comment.narrative: 11b. [as above]

11b. Key recommendations on emerging issues relevant to mainstreaming PAs in national development plans and implementation of Aichi targets are promoted at CBD COPs and other international policy arenas.

The key elements of the PoS will be carried forward to three upcoming events: UNFCCC Paris December 2015; IUCN WCC September 2016; and CBD COP Mexico, October 2016.
Planning is underway for each. For UNFCCC Paris 2015, three to five African delegates will be supported to present PA and climate change solutions from various regions in sahel / sub-saharan regions.
For WCC and various lead-in events to CBD COP in Mexico, specific activities will be evaluated in Q315 through to Q116.

description.narrative: 11c. [as above]

comment.narrative: 11c. [as above]

Elements of project support contributed to the Sendai framework for Disaster Risk Reduction. In Q315 project elements related to PAs and DRR will be incorporated into implementation framework for the Sendai+10 agreement.

title.narrative: PIMS 5364 LEAD MSP: Reducing lead contamination

description.narrative: To reduce lead in paint and ULABs in Indonesia and the Philippines
To reduce lead in paint and ULABs in Indonesia and the Philippines
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Promote the environmentally sound management (ESM) of two sources of potential lead poisoning in the selected countries in Asia, lead in paint and used lead acid batteries (ULABs), in ways that minimize significant adverse effects on human health and the environment

comment.narrative: While the project document has not yet been signed by the Government of the Philippines, Blacksmith Institute has begun laying the groundwork for a successful project, beginning its focus in Indonesia. To date, toxic sites have been identified and assessed, research has begun to document the Used Lead Acid Battery (ULAB) Supply Chain in the Jakarta area, the Inception Workshop was held in Jakarta, and a training was conducted in the use of the International Lead Management Center's (ILMC) benchmarking assessment tool.

description.narrative: Scope of pollution and human health exposure risks due to current practices in ULAB recycling/ smelting evaluated and better understood by government agencies and other stakeholders
Number of ULAB sites added to inventory (including no. of people impacted)

comment.narrative: Toxic Sites Identification Program database has identified ~100 ULAB lead contaminated sites globally, more than half of which are in Asia.
At least 150 lead contaminated sites from ULAB recycling/smelting assessed.

In this reporting period, 53 lead-contaminated sites have been assessed and confirmed to be of great health risk to local populations in the two project countries, of which:
27 sites were in Indonesia and 26 sites were in the Philippines.
An additional 20 sites were assessed and require further study.
Finally, 4 sites in Indonesia were assessed and determined to be low-risk, not primarily lead-contaminated, or not of serious health concern

description.narrative: Reports on scope and impacts of ULAB recycling globally and in selected project countries available

comment.narrative: Toxic Sites Identification Program database has identified ~100 ULAB lead contaminated sites globally, more than half of which are in Asia.

The team is waiting for the Project Document to be signed by the government of the Philippines before beginning project activities that will require paying site investigators and researchers

comment.narrative: Toxic Sites Identification Program database has identified ~100 ULAB lead contaminated sites globally, more than half of which are in Asia.

The TSIP database contains prioritized list of sites in each country. Additionally in Indonesia, the team has consulted with the Ministry of Environment and identified 4 priority sites for ULAB interventions over the next 5 years. The team has visited those 4 sites and prioritized one site for the remediation efforts under the GEF project.

Basel guidelines are under review currently by a working group established by the Basel Secretariat. The guidelines are expected to be amended in the fall of 2015.
The Blacksmith Institute Technical Advisory Board (TAB) will review these revised guidelines and provide feedback to the secretariat as well as making country-specific recommendations to the governments that will support this outcome.

description.narrative: Recommendations regarding feasible steps and solutions to mitigate risks from lead contamination and to phase out lead in paint and unsafe ULAB recovery, recycling and smelting practices have been drafted.
Number of functioning multi-stakeholder workgroups established.

comment.narrative: Regulations related to active lead emissions for lead smelters/ recyclers exist, but often are either not enforced or not strictly enforced.
Multistakeholder working group established.

As part of the Inception Workshop preparations, a Multistakeholder working group was established in Indonesia consisting of government ministries, industry representatives, small-scale business representatives, and a local lead advocacy community organization. It is anticipated that additional community, advocacy, and NGO groups will be represented as the project grows. The initial meeting of the group was held June 30, 2014.
